III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:

• Consultant spoke with Chief Administrator about the new electronic system for
record keeping called WeCare. Technical assistance was provided to ensure
for case service plans the date of the report, date of the end of the report
period, and date of the signature of the author of the report is the same date.
Currently in the system it can be viewed the date the report was submitted
which aligns with the report date and end of reporting period date but the
signature date of the author of the report is not until full corrections are made
on the report. It should also be noted upon roll out of the system there was a
glitch that the author of the report could not officially sign the report until the
youth signature was provided, this was corrected immediately as reports were
approved in the system but could not be signed off on until the youth's
signature.
V. CONSULTATION

• During the time of the onsite visit, there was no consultation requested or
required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were 2 substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. There were two substantiated incidents of male treatment this licensing
period. Each incident is as followed:
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001532 dated 08/7/2024 which found the facility in
non-compliance of a staff member hitting a youth in the face. A Corrective Action
Plan (CAP) dated 08/23/24 was approved that included the staff member involved
being terminated from employment, “community meeting emotional check in” was
added for the supervisor to complete during the shift, and a training of role play
scenarios of youth behaviors was completed with all staff to help staff understand
the appropriate responses to youth’s behaviors.
Special Investigation 2024SIC001548 dated 09/23/24 which found the facility in
non-compliance of a staff member not completing room checks and falsifying the
documentation stating he completed the forms. A CAP dated 10/14/24 was
approved that included the staff member involved being terminated, administration
completing random video review of room checks for compliance, and the bed check
policy was reviewed with the team.

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 4 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency has submitted 4 acceptable correction action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP as follows:
2024 Interim: Correction Action Plan (CAP) was recorded during this reporting
period as a result of the Interim Inspection completed on 02/08/2024. The CAP
contained one violation of CCI Rule 400.4113 (1) (e) where one of the twenty-five
new employees had two references that were dated over a year old from the
employee’s hire dated. The CAP contained one violation of CCI Rule 400.4113
(1) (i) where one of the twenty-five new employee files reviewed did not have
documentation of verification the employee has not been determined to be the
perpetrator of child abuse or neglect within the appropriate time frame. The CAP
included Human Resource department will create an onboarding checklists tool
and updated their internal policies to make sure the timeliness of items needs is
correct per the rules.
Special Investigation 2024SIC001437 with CAP approval date of 07/24/2024 was
a result of a staff member not following the facility internal policy of using
appropriate language around the youth. The CAP included the staff member
involved in the situation was provided a letter of expectation and provided
additional training. The facility also created a standard of if a male staff is hired to
work directly with female youth unit, they will receive an individualized coaching
plan to ensure appropriate interactions are occurring. The facility successfully
completed all the action steps within their approved CAP.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001532 dated 08/7/2024 which found the facility in
non-compliance of a staff member hitting a youth in the face. A Corrective Action
Plan (CAP) dated 08/23/24 was approved that included the staff member involved
being terminated from employment, “community meeting emotional check in” was
added for the supervisor to complete during the shift, and a training of role play
scenarios of youth behaviors was completed with all staff to help staff understand
the appropriate responses to youth’s behaviors. The facility successfully
completed all the action steps within their approved CAP.
Special Investigation 2024SIC001548 dated 09/23/24 which found the facility in
non-compliance of a staff member not completing room checks and falsifying the
documentation stating he completed the forms. A CAP dated 10/14/24 was
approved that included the staff member involved being terminated,
administration completing random video review of room checks for compliance,
and the bed check policy was reviewed with the team. The facility is currently
complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor CAP
compliance with no noted concerns.

Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator Assessment was received and reviewed on January 24, 2025.
Chief Administrator reported the continued barrier to the facility is hiring, especially
for the clinician role in the Zondervan Unit. This role is currently being met but the
unit would benefit from having their own clinician. It is noted that the human
resource department has been able to fill openings, but it does take time to
develop the competencies of seasoned staff. Over this past year, the agency as a
whole has implemented a new electronic record system, called WeCare. There
has been an adjustment period for all levels of the residential to re-learn practices
for timely, effective, and accurate documentation within the new digital system.
The facility has also implemented the Sanctuary model to their program which has
been help for being individual of hiring and coaching the right staff into the right
positions. Another highlight from this report is during this reporting period, the
facility had not unplanned discharges, 30-day letter notices or youth discharge
because of AWOL.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported feeling well equipped to doing their jobs. It was reported they have
enjoyed the check ins with their direct supervisor and feel well supported by their
team.
Three youth interviews were conducted during the inspection and no issues or
concerns were raised. The youth reported having a positive relationship with staff
and feel safe on the unit. The youth reported they would like to do more outings in
the community but also understand it based on their level system within the
program to make sure they are safe.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The onsite inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on January 7, 2025.
There were no issues or safety concerns noted.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes. It is recommended that the agency be issued a renewal of their regular
license.
